body.p:
Couchbase Server 4.5 [Beta] builds on the advances of version 4 with faster, simpler, and more secure data processing. The new features include memory-optimized global indexes, indexing of embedded arrays, the ability to perform partial reads and writes to a JSON document without transferring the full document, an integrated Query Workbench in the Web Console, flexible JOINS with N1QL, and a new, fast and resilient enterprise backup and restore tool designed for big data and more.
This is a Beta version of Couchbase Server 4.5 and is intended for development purposes only. We consider Beta releases to have some rough edges and bugs, and may change significantly before the final GA release. This release is not supported in production.
The Beta release does not support upgrading from an earlier version of Couchbase Server.

section.title: Faster
section.p: Couchbase Server version 4.5 enables performance, in some cases by an order of magnitude (10x), with enhancements to core data operations (get/set), secondary global indexes, enhancements to JOINs and additional query optimization rules. These, along with the features added in version 4.1 such as prepared execution of N1QL statements and covering indexes, give querying and indexing a significant boost.

dlentry.dt: Fast Partial Reads and Writes to JSON Documents
dlentry.dd: With Couchbase Server 4.5, applications no longer have to address the entire document. With the extended APIs, developers can operate on parts of a document without having to send the entire document back and forth between client and server. This can result in over 10 times faster performance with large documents. The result is enhanced performance and efficiency in the network IO path, especially when documents in the system are large. For more information, see .

Version 4 of Couchbase Server introduced which are independently partitioned away from data for faster N1QL queries. Couchbase Server 4.5 provides additional tuning for index processing and index scans. The new memory-optimized indexing provide over 20x improvement to query latencies and fresher index under heavy mutation rates (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE). Unlike other databases, Couchbase Server global indexes are built to isolate the impact of indexing on performance of mutations, data ingest, and bulk data modifications using N1QL INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE and MERGE statements. Couchbase Server 4.5 memory-optimized indexes further enhances index processing and isolation of impact of indexing on the incoming workload.
You can enable the new memory-optimized global indexes through the index settings under the Settings tab in the Couchbase Server Web Console. For more information, see .

N1QL provides a considerable number of verbs to process embedded structures and arrays such as UNNEST and ANY/EVERY operators. With the new array indexing feature, developers can optimize the execution of the queries. The new index can optimize queries that are looking for specific array elements and can result in multiple orders of magnitude improvement on query latency and throughput. Arrays are indexed using the new ARRAY keyword in CREATE INDEX statement in N1QL. For more information, see .

dlentry.dt: Faster Read-Your-Own-Write (RYOW) Consistency with N1QL Queries
dlentry.dd: Tunable consistency for N1QL and MapReduce queries helps improve the query performance. Using the previous versions, you could query data using eventual or strict consistency flag. With strictly consistent queries, the staleness parameter is set to false per query, which ensures that the query uses the request timestamp token to generate the results. With version 4.5, you can choose to grab the timestamp tokens from your last update, which ensures that you read your last update instead of the query request timestamp token. RYOW consistency provides the optimization required by applications that have to deal with high mutation rates but cannot compromise on consistency guarantees. See for details.

dlentry.dt: Improved Index Write Performance with Circular Writes
dlentry.dd: Global indexes use the new ForestDB engine for index storage. ForestDB uses an append-only architecture where full compaction is run as and when pages are orphaned with the appending writes. With version 4.5, ForestDB introduces circular compaction as an alternative to full compaction. Circular compaction reduces the disk size and IO bandwidth demands for indexes and reduces the requirement to run frequent full compaction operations. This improves the overall index maintenance and index read and write performance greatly for global indexes. Circular write is enabled by default. You can change the compaction settings from the Settings Auto-Compaction tab on the Web Console. See for more information.

With version 4.5, N1QL introduces an extended JOIN syntax for added flexibility in JOINs. The new JOIN ON KEY … FOR keyword allows developers to specify JOIN operations that can use the left or the right keyspace for the JOIN. With the extended syntax, N1QL also makes better use of indexes to perform the JOIN operation faster across the two sides, and substantially lowers JOIN latencies. For example, SELECT * FROM `beer-sample` brewery JOIN `beer-sample` beer ON KEY beer.brewery_id FOR brewery WHERE beer.type="beer" AND brewery.type="brewery" AND brewery.state="California";. For more information, see Indexed Joins.

section.title: Simpler
section.p: Development and administration become simpler with Couchbase Server 4.5 with new integrated query development experience, smart schema inference on your data, enhanced query monitoring capabilities, a new robust and high performance enterprise backup and restore utility, an integrated full-text search service, and many more enhancements to N1QL and global secondary indexes..

dlentry.dd: Couchbase Server 4.5 also provides a simple and visual way to develop and design queries with auto-complete for your N1QL statements. Query Workbench analyzes your bucket data to infer schemas of your document data and allows the execution of ad hoc queries directly from the Web Console. Query results are displayed in JSON, table, and tree formats, and can be saved. To use the new integrated Query Workbench, switch to the new Query tab in the Couchbase Server Web Console. For more information, see .

In Couchbase Server 4.5, N1QL adds several new keyspaces under the “system:” namespace to the existing list that provides information on indexes, buckets, and more. The new keyspaces under “system:" allow monitoring active requests, completed requests, system information and more. For a full list of new system keyspaces added to N1QL, see .

In previous releases, the cbq command line tool has been the central point for executing N1QL queries. Command line access to N1QL has been greatly improved in this release, and the new command line access provides smart connection management and full scriptability with version 4.5. For more information, see .

dlentry.dt: Integrated Full Text Search (FTS) and new Search Service [Developer Preview]
dlentry.dd:
Full Text Search (FTS) enables you to create, manage, and query full text indexes on JSON documents stored in a Couchbase bucket. FTS provides a language-aware manner of searching with relevance ranking (scoring) for results. The Full Text Search feature is still considered experimental and the UI or the functionality may change. The What's New? page lists the FTS features added in the Beta release.
For more information on search service and full-text search, see .

Couchbase Server 4.5 provides a new enterprise backup and restore tool that can back up larger datasets with significantly higher performance than before. The scalable, high-performance backup and restore tool allows Couchbase Server to provide faster and more scalable recovery options to better integrate with Disaster Recovery planning. See for detailed information.
Couchbase Server 4.5 supports Debian 8 platform in addition to the platforms supported by the earlier version (version 4.1). See for the complete list of supported platforms in this release.

ul.li:
N1QL enhancements such as array insert function, object add, put, and remove functions, and more.
Array insert function to insert a value into a specific position in an array and return the new array. See for details.
New functions to add, put, and remove objects. See for details.
Duration to string conversion functions: Durations have been used consistently in the body of the results document (for example, elapsedTime) but now are also used in some keyspaces such as active_requests and completed_requests. The conversion functions support nano- (ns) , micro- ( μs), milli- (ms) and second (s) time units. See for details.
Simplified administration for large node counts (>100 node clusters).

section.title: More Secure
section.p: Security continues to be a strong priority for Couchbase Server development. Previous versions have added many security-related features, and version 4.5 continues to do so by adding support for X.509 certificates and Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) for administrators.

dlentry.dd: With Couchbase Server 4.5, you can now integrate your signed certificate authority within Couchbase Server. X.509 certificates provide strongly trusted, on-the-wire encryption for client-server communication and across data centers. The new capability also makes it simple for administrators to manage and rotate certificates without application downtime. You can find detailed information about X.509 certificates here.

With version 4.5, Couchbase Server provides Role-Based Access Control for administrators. Aside from the existing encryption and auditing facilities, RBAC provides fine grain control over administrative access and simplifies compliance with governance rules. You can control administrative roles from the Settings tab in the Web Console. See for details.
